RTCPeerConnection.summary:
The RTCPeerConnection interface represents a WebRTC connection between the local computer and a remote peer.
It provides methods to connect to a remote peer, maintain and monitor the connection, and close the connection once it's no longer needed.

remarks.para:
-
-Get started with WebRTC
-TutorRoom: Node.js HTML video capture, peer-to-peer video and file sharing application (source on GitHub)

RTCPeerConnectionAddIceCandidate.summary: The addIceCandidate() method of the interface adds a new remote candidate to the connection's remote description, which describes the state of the remote end of the connection.

remarks.para:
When a website or app using receives a new ICE candidate from the remote peer over its signaling channel, it delivers the newly-received candidate to the browser's {{Glossary("ICE")}} agent by calling RTCPeerConnection.addIceCandidate().
This adds this new remote candidate to the RTCPeerConnection's remote description, which describes the state of the remote end of the connection.

If the candidate parameter is missing or a value of null is given when calling addIceCandidate(), the added ICE candidate is an "end-of-candidates" indicator.
The same is the case if the value of the specified object's is either missing or an empty string (""), it signals that all remote candidates have been delivered.
The end-of-candidates notification is transmitted to the remote peer using a candidate with an a-line value of end-of-candidates.

During negotiation, your app will likely receive many candidates which you'll deliver to the ICE agent in this way, allowing it to build up a list of potential connection methods.
This is covered in more detail in the articles WebRTC connectivity and
Signaling and video calling.

-WebRTC API
-Signaling and video calling
-Introduction to WebRTC protocols
-WebRTC connectivity
-Lifetime of a WebRTC session

RTCPeerConnectionAddIceCandidate.returns:
A that is fulfilled when the candidate has been successfully added to the remote peer's description by the ICE agent.
The promise does not receive any input parameters.

RTCPeerConnectionAddStream.summary:
IMPORTANT Deprecated The addStream() method of the interface adds a as a local source of audio or video.
Instead of using this obsolete method, you should instead use once for each track you wish to send to the remote peer.

remarks.para:
If the is set to closed, an InvalidStateError is raised.
If the is set to stable, the event is sent on the to indicate that {{Glossary("ICE")}} negotiation must be repeated to consider the new stream.
-WebRTC

RTCPeerConnectionAddstream.summary: IMPORTANT Deprecated The obsolete addstream event is sent to an when new media, in the form of a object, has been added to it.

blockquote.para: This event has been removed from the WebRTC specification. You should instead watch for the event, which is sent for each media track added to the RTCPeerConnection.

remarks.para: You can, similarly, watch for streams to be removed from the connection by monitoring the event.
This event is not cancelable and does not bubble.

-WebRTC API
-
-

RTCPeerConnectionAddTrack.summary: The addTrack() method of the interface adds a new media track to the set of tracks which will be transmitted to the other peer.

blockquote.para:
Adding a track to a connection triggers renegotiation by firing a event.
See Starting negotiation for details.

remarks.para:
-WebRTC
-Introduction to the Real-time Transport Protocol (RTP)
-

RTCPeerConnectionAddTrack.returns:
The object which will be used to transmit the media data.
NOTEEvery RTCRtpSender is paired with an to make up an .
The associated receiver is muted (indicating that it is not able to deliver packets) until and unless one or more streams are added to the receiver by the remote peer.

RTCPeerConnectionAddTransceiver.summary:
The addTransceiver() method of the interface creates a new and adds it to the set of transceivers associated with the RTCPeerConnection.
Each transceiver represents a bidirectional stream, with both an and an associated with it.

remarks.para:
-WebRTC API
-Introduction to the Real-time Transport Protocol (RTP)
- also creates transceivers
- and

RTCPeerConnectionAddTransceiver.returns: The object which will be used to exchange the media data.

RTCPeerConnectionCanTrickleIceCandidates.summary: The canTrickleIceCandidates read-only property of the interface returns a boolean value which indicates whether or not the remote peer can accept trickled ICE candidates.

remarks.para: ICE trickling is the process of continuing to send candidates after the initial offer or answer has already been sent to the other peer.

This property is only set after having called . Ideally, your signaling protocol provides a way to detect trickling support, so that you don't need to rely on this property.
A WebRTC browser will always support trickle ICE. If trickling isn't supported, or you aren't able to tell, you can check for a falsy value for this property and then wait until the value of changes to "completed" before creating and sending the initial offer.
That way, the offer contains all of the candidates.

-WebRTC
-
-Lifetime of a WebRTC session

RTCPeerConnectionCanTrickleIceCandidates.value:
A boolean value that is true if the remote peer can accept trickled ICE candidates and false if it cannot.
If no remote peer has been established, this value is null.
NOTEThis property's value is determined once the local peer has called ;
the provided description is used by the ICE agent to determine whether or not the remote peer supports trickled ICE candidates.

RTCPeerConnectionClose.summary: The close() method of the interface closes the current peer connection.

remarks.para:
Calling this method terminates the RTCPeerConnection's ICE agent, ending any ongoing ICE processing and any active streams.
This also releases any resources in use by the ICE agent, including TURN permissions.
All objects are considered to be stopped once this returns (they may still be in the process of stopping, but for all intents and purposes, they're stopped).
Once this method returns, the signaling state as returned by is closed.

Make sure that you delete all references to the previous before attempting to create a new one that connects to the same remote peer, as not doing so might result in some errors depending on the browser.

-WebRTC
-
-

RTCPeerConnectionConnectionState.summary: The connectionState read-only property of the interface indicates the current state of the peer connection by returning one of the following string values: new, connecting, connected, disconnected, failed, or closed.

remarks.para: This state essentially represents the aggregate state of all ICE transports (which are of type or ) being used by the connection.
When this property's value changes, a event is sent to the instance.

-Lifetime of a WebRTC session
-
-
-
-WebRTC

RTCPeerConnectionConnectionState.value:
A string representing the current state of the connection.
This can take on of the following values:

RTCPeerConnectionConnectionstatechange.summary:
The connectionstatechange event is sent to the onconnectionstatechange event handler on an object after a new track has been added to an which is part of the connection.
The new connection state can be found in , and is one of the string values: new, connecting, connected, disconnected, failed, or closed.

remarks.para: This event is not cancelable and does not bubble.

-WebRTC API
-WebRTC connectivity
-Lifetime of a WebRTC session
-

RTCPeerConnectionCreateAnswer.summary: The createAnswer() method of the interface creates an {{Glossary("SDP")}} answer to an offer received from a remote peer during the offer/answer negotiation of a WebRTC connection.

remarks.para:
The answer contains information about any media already attached to the session, codecs and options supported by the browser, and any ICE candidates already gathered.
The answer is delivered to the returned , and should then be sent to the source of the offer to continue the negotiation process.

RTCPeerConnectionCreateAnswer.returns: A {{jsxref("Promise")}} that fulfills with an object containing the same properties as an objects:

RTCPeerConnectionCreateDataChannel.summary:
The createDataChannel() method of the interface creates a new channel linked with the remote peer, over which any kind of data may be transmitted.
This can be useful for back-channel content, such as images, file transfer, text chat, game update packets, and so forth.

remarks.para: If the new data channel is the first one added to the connection, renegotiation is started by delivering a event.

-
-A simple RTCDataChannel sample
-

RTCPeerConnectionCreateDataChannel.returns: A new object with the specified label, configured using the options specified by options if that parameter is included; otherwise, the defaults listed above are established.

RTCPeerConnectionCreateDTMFSender.summary: IMPORTANT Deprecated The createDTMFSender() method of the interface creates a new object associated with the specified , which can be used to send DTMF tones over the connection.

remarks.para: This method is deprecated and should not be used. Instead, use the property to access the DTMF sender associated with a specific sender.

-WebRTC
-
-
-

RTCPeerConnectionCreateOffer.summary: The createOffer() method of the interface initiates the creation of an {{Glossary("SDP")}} offer for the purpose of starting a new WebRTC connection to a remote peer.

remarks.para: The SDP offer includes information about any objects already attached to the WebRTC session, codec, and options supported by the browser, and any candidates already gathered by the {{Glossary("ICE")}} agent, for the purpose of being sent over the signaling channel to a potential peer to request a connection or to update the configuration of an existing connection.

RTCPeerConnectionCreateOffer.returns: A {{jsxref("Promise")}} that fulfills with an object containing the same properties as an objects:

RTCPeerConnectionCurrentLocalDescription.summary:
The currentLocalDescription read-only property of the interface returns an object describing the local end of the connection as it was most recently successfully negotiated since the last time the finished negotiating and connecting to a remote peer.
Also included is a list of any ICE candidates that may already have been generated by the ICE agent since the offer or answer represented by the description was first instantiated.

remarks.para:
To change the currentLocalDescription, call , which triggers a series of events which leads to this value being set.
For details on what exactly happens and why the change isn't necessarily instantaneous, see Pending and current descriptions in the WebRTC Connectivity page.

blockquote.para:
Unlike , this value represents the actual current state of the local end of the connection;
localDescription may specify a description which the connection is currently in the process of switching over to.

remarks.para:
-, ,
-, , ,
-WebRTC

RTCPeerConnectionCurrentLocalDescription.value:
The current description of the local end of the connection, if one has been set.
If none has been successfully set, this value is null.

RTCPeerConnectionCurrentRemoteDescriptio.summary:
The currentRemoteDescription read-only property of the interface returns an
object describing the remote end of the connection as it was most recently successfully negotiated since the last time the finished negotiating and connecting to a remote peer.
Also included is a list of any ICE candidates that may already have been generated by the ICE agent since the offer or answer represented by the description was first instantiated.

remarks.para:
To change the currentRemoteDescription, call , which triggers a series of events which leads to this value being set.
For details on what exactly happens and why the change isn't necessarily instantaneous, see Pending and current descriptions in the WebRTC Connectivity page.

blockquote.para:
Unlike , this value represents the actual current state of the local end of the connection;
remoteDescription may specify a description which the connection is currently in the process of switching over to.

remarks.para:
-, ,
-, ,
-WebRTC

RTCPeerConnectionCurrentRemoteDescriptio.value:
The current description of the remote end of the connection, if one has been set.
If none has been successfully set, this value is null.

RTCPeerConnectionDatachannel.summary: A datachannel event is sent to an instance when an has been added to the connection, as a result of the remote peer calling .

blockquote.para: This event is not dispatched when the local end of the connection creates the channel.

remarks.para: This event is not cancelable and does not bubble.

-WebRTC API
-Using WebRTC data channels
-A simple RTCDataChannel sample
-
-

RTCPeerConnectionGenerateCertificate.summary: The generateCertificate() static function of the interface creates an X.509 certificate and corresponding private key, returning a promise that resolves with the new once it's generated.

remarks.para:
-WebRTC API
-Web Crypto API
-Website security
-Web security
-Symmetric-key cryptography
-

RTCPeerConnectionGenerateCertificate.returns: A promise which resolves to a new object containing a new key based on the specified options.

RTCPeerConnectionGetConfiguration.summary: The getConfiguration() method of the interface returns an object which indicates the current configuration of the on which the method is called.

remarks.para:
The returned configuration is the last configuration applied via , or if
setConfiguration() hasn't been called, the configuration the RTCPeerConnection was constructed with.
The configuration includes a list of the ICE servers used by the connection, information about transport policies, and identity information.

RTCPeerConnectionGetConfiguration.returns:
An object describing the 's current configuration.
See RTCPeerConnection() for more information on what options are allowed.

RTCPeerConnectionGetIdentityAssertion.summary:
The getIdentityAssertion() method of the interface initiates the gathering of an identity assertion.
This has an effect only if the is not "closed".

remarks.para: It is not expected for the application dealing with the RTCPeerConnection: this is automatically done; an explicit call only allows to anticipate the need.
-WebRTC

RTCPeerConnectionGetIdentityAssertion.returns: A which resolves to an identity assertion encoded as a string.

RTCPeerConnectionGetReceivers.summary:
The getReceivers() method of the interface returns an array of objects, each of which represents one RTP receiver.
Each RTP receiver manages the reception and decoding of data for a on an .

remarks.para:
-WebRTC
-

RTCPeerConnectionGetReceivers.returns:
An array of objects, one for each track on the connection.
The array is empty if there are no RTP receivers on the connection.The order of the returned RTCRtpReceiver instances is not defined by the specification, and may change from one call to getReceivers() to the next.The array does not include receivers associated with transceivers that have been stopped (following offer/answer).

RTCPeerConnectionGetSenders.summary:
The getSenders() method of the interface returns an array of objects, each of which represents the RTP sender responsible for transmitting one track's data.
A sender object provides methods and properties for examining and controlling the encoding and transmission of the track's data.

remarks.para:
-WebRTC
-

RTCPeerConnectionGetSenders.returns:
An array of objects, one for each track on the connection.
The array is empty if there are no RTP senders on the connection.The order of the returned RTCRtpSender instances is not defined by the specification, and may change from one call to getSenders() to the next.The array does not include senders associated with transceivers that have been stopped (following offer/answer).

RTCPeerConnectionGetStats.summary: The getStats() method of the interface returns a promise which resolves with data providing statistics about either the overall connection or about the specified .
RTCPeerConnectionGetStats.returns:
A {{jsxref("Promise")}} which resolves with an object providing connection statistics.
The report's contents depend on the selector and other details of the connection.

RTCPeerConnectionGetTransceivers.summary: The getTransceivers() method of the interface returns a list of the objects being used to send and receive data on the connection.

remarks.para:
-WebRTC API
-Signaling and video calling
-
-

RTCPeerConnectionGetTransceivers.returns:
An array of the objects representing the transceivers handling sending and receiving all media on the RTCPeerConnection.
The array is in the order in which the transceivers were added to the connection.
The array does not include transceivers that have already been stopped (following offer/answer).

RTCPeerConnectionIcecandidateerror.summary: The WebRTC API event icecandidateerror is sent to an if an error occurs while performing ICE negotiations through a {{Glossary("STUN")}} or {{Glossary("TURN")}} server. The event object is of type , and contains information describing the error in some amount of detail.

remarks.para: This event is not cancelable and does not bubble.

RTCPeerConnectionIcecandidate.summary: An icecandidate event is sent to an when:

remarks.para: In the first two cases, the event handler should transmit the candidate to the remote peer over the signaling channel so the remote peer can add it to its set of remote candidates.
This event is not cancelable and does not bubble.

-WebRTC API
-Signaling and video calling

RTCPeerConnectionIceConnectionState.summary: The iceConnectionState read-only property of the interface returns a string which state of the {{Glossary("ICE")}} agent associated with the : new, checking, connected, completed, failed, disconnected, and closed.

remarks.para:
It describes the current state of the ICE agent and its connection to the ICE server;
that is, the STUN or TURN server.
You can detect when this value has changed by watching for the event.

-WebRTC API
-
-

RTCPeerConnectionIceConnectionState.value: The current state of the ICE agent and its connection. The value is one of the following strings:

RTCPeerConnectionIceconnectionstatechang.summary:
An iceconnectionstatechange event is sent to an object each time the {{Glossary("ICE")}} connection state changes during the negotiation process.
The new ICE connection state is available in the object's property.

remarks.para: One common task performed by the iceconnectionstatechange event listener is to trigger ICE restart when the state changes to failed.
This event is not cancelable and does not bubble.

-WebRTC API
-
-

RTCPeerConnectionIceGatheringState.summary:
The iceGatheringState read-only property of the interface returns a string that describes the overall ICE gathering state for this connection.
This lets you detect, for example, when collection of ICE candidates has finished.

remarks.para: You can detect when the value of this property changes by watching for an event of type .

Note that iceGatheringState represents the overall gathering state of the connection, including every used by every and every on the entire connection.
This contrasts with , which represents the gathering state for a single transport.

-
-WebRTC

RTCPeerConnectionIcegatheringstatechange.summary:
The icegatheringstatechange event is sent to the onicegatheringstatechange event handler on an when the state of the {{Glossary("ICE")}} candidate gathering process changes.
This signifies that the value of the connection's property has changed.

remarks.para: When ICE first starts to gather connection candidates, the value changes from new to gathering to indicate that the process of collecting candidate configurations for the connection has begun. When the value changes to complete, all of the transports that make up the RTCPeerConnection have finished gathering ICE candidates.

blockquote.para: While you can determine that ICE candidate gathering is complete by watching for icegatheringstatechange events and checking for the value of to become complete, you can also have your handler for the event look to see if its property is null. This also indicates that collection of candidates is finished.

remarks.para: This event is not cancelable and does not bubble.

-WebRTC API
-Signaling and video calling
-WebRTC connectivity
-Lifetime of a WebRTC session

RTCPeerConnectionLocalDescription.summary:
The localDescription read-only property of the interface returns an describing the session for the local end of the connection.
If it has not yet been set, this is null.

remarks.para:
-, ,
-, , ,
-WebRTC

RTCPeerConnectionNegotiationneeded.summary:
A negotiationneeded event is sent to the when negotiation of the connection through the signaling channel is required.
This occurs both during the initial setup of the connection as well as any time a change to the communication environment requires reconfiguring the connection.

remarks.para: The negotiationneeded event is first dispatched to the when media is first added to the connection. This starts the process of {{Glossary("ICE")}} negotiation by instructing your code to begin exchanging ICE candidates through the signaling server. See Signaling transaction flow for a description of the signaling process that begins with a negotiationneeded event.
This event is not cancelable and does not bubble.

-WebRTC API
-Signaling and video calling
-Lifetime of a WebRTC session
-WebRTC connectivity
-Introduction to WebRTC protocols

RTCPeerConnectionPeerIdentity.summary:
The peerIdentity read-only property of the interface returns a JavaScript {{jsxref("Promise")}} that resolves to an which contains a string identifying the remote peer.
Once this promise resolves successfully, the resulting identity is the target peer identity and cannot change for the duration of the connection.

remarks.para: -WebRTC API

RTCPeerConnectionPeerIdentity.value:
A JavaScript {{jsxref("Promise")}} which resolves to an that describes the remote peer's identity.If an error occurs while attempting to validate an incoming identity assertion (that is, the information describing a peer's identity), the promise is rejected.
If there isn't already a target peer identity, peerIdentity is set to a newly created promise and the process begins again, until the process succeeds or no further attempts to authenticate occur.
NOTEThe promise returned by cannot resolve until any target peer identity that's been set is validated.
If the identity hasn't been validated yet, the promise returned by setRemoteDescription() will be rejected.
If there's no target peer identity, setRemoteDescription() doesn't need to wait for validation to occur before it resolves.

RTCPeerConnectionPendingLocalDescription.summary: The pendingLocalDescription read-only property of the interface returns an object describing a pending configuration change for the local end of the connection.

remarks.para:
This does not describe the connection as it currently stands, but as it may exist in the near future.
Use or to get the current state of the endpoint.
For details on the difference, see Pending and current descriptions in the WebRTC Connectivity page.

-, ,
-, , ,
-WebRTC

RTCPeerConnectionPendingLocalDescription.value:
If a local description change is in progress, this is an describing the proposed configuration.
Otherwise, this returns null.

RTCPeerConnectionPendingRemoteDescriptio.summary: The pendingRemoteDescription read-only property of the interface returns an object describing a pending configuration change for the remote end of the connection.

remarks.para:
This does not describe the connection as it currently stands, but as it may exist in the near future.
Use or to get the current session
description for the remote endpoint.
For details on the difference, see Pending and current descriptions in the WebRTC Connectivity page.

-,
,
-,
,
,
-WebRTC

RTCPeerConnectionPendingRemoteDescriptio.value:
If a remote description change is in progress, this is an describing the proposed configuration.
Otherwise, this returns null.

RTCPeerConnectionRemoteDescription.summary:
The remoteDescription read-only property of the interface returns a describing the session (which includes configuration and media information) for the remote end of the connection.
If this hasn't been set yet, this is null.

remarks.para: The returned value typically reflects a remote description which has been received over the signaling server (as either an offer or an answer) and then put into effect by your code calling in response.

-, ,
-, , ,
-WebRTC

RTCPeerConnectionRemoteDescription.value:
On a more fundamental level, the returned value is the value of if that property isn't
null;
otherwise, the value of is returned.
See Pending and current descriptions in the WebRTC Connectivity page for details on this algorithm and why it's used.

RTCPeerConnectionRemoveStream.summary:
IMPORTANT Deprecated The removeStream() method of the interface removes a as a local source of audio or video.
If the negotiation already happened, a new one will be needed for the remote peer to be able to use it.
Because this method has been deprecated, you should instead use if your target browser versions have implemented it.

remarks.para:
If the is set to "closed", an InvalidStateError is raised.
If the is set to "stable", the event is sent on the .

-WebRTC
-
-
-

RTCPeerConnectionRemovestream.summary:
IMPORTANT Deprecated The obsolete removestream event was sent to an to inform it that a had been removed from the connection.
You can use the RTCPeerConnection interface's onremovestream property to set a handler for this event.

remarks.para: This is the counterpart to the event, which is also obsolete.

blockquote.para: This event has been removed from the WebRTC specification in favor of the existing event on the remote and the corresponding event handler property of the remote . The API is now track-based, so having zero tracks in the remote stream is equivalent to the remote stream being removed, which caused a removestream event.

remarks.para: This event is not cancelable and does not bubble.

-WebRTC API
-
-

RTCPeerConnectionRemoveTrack.summary:
The removeTrack() method of the interface tells the local end of the connection to stop sending media from the specified track, without actually removing the corresponding from the list of senders as reported by .
If the track is already stopped, or is not in the connection's senders list, this method has no effect.

remarks.para:
If the connection has already been negotiated ( is set to "stable"), it is marked as needing to be negotiated again; the remote peer won't experience the change until this negotiation occurs.
A event is sent to the to let the local end know this negotiation must occur.
-WebRTC API

RTCPeerConnectionRestartIce.summary:
The restartIce() method of the interface allows a web application to request that {{Glossary("ICE")}} candidate gathering be redone on both ends of the connection.
This simplifies the process by allowing the same method to be used by either the caller or the receiver to trigger an ICE restart.

remarks.para: After restartIce() returns, the offer returned by the next call to is automatically configured to trigger ICE restart on both the local peer (once the local peer has been set) and on the remote peer, once the offer is sent across your signaling mechanism and the remote peer has set its description as well.

restartIce() causes the
event to be fired on the RTCPeerConnection to inform the application that it should perform negotiation using its signaling channel.

If negotiation fails to completeeither due to rollback or because incoming offers are in the process of being negotiatedthe will remember that you requested ICE restart.
The next time the connection's changes to stable, the connection will fire the event.
This process continues until an ICE restart has been successfully completed.

-WebRTC API
-Lifetime of a WebRTC session
-Signaling and video calling

RTCPeerConnectionRTCPeerConnection.summary: The RTCPeerConnection() constructor returns a newly-created , which represents a connection between the local device and a remote peer.

remarks.para:
-Signaling and video calling
-WebRTC architecture overview
-Lifetime of a WebRTC session
-

RTCPeerConnectionRTCPeerConnection.returns: A newly-created object, configured as described by configuration, if specified; otherwise, configured to appropriate basic defaults.

RTCPeerConnectionSctp.summary:
The sctp read-only property of the interface returns an describing the {{Glossary("SCTP")}} transport over which SCTP data is being sent and received.
If SCTP hasn't been negotiated, this value is null.

remarks.para: The SCTP transport is used for transmitting and receiving data for any and all s on the peer connection.

-WebRTC
-
-
-SCTP

RTCPeerConnectionSctp.value: A object describing the SCTP transport being used by the for transmitting and receiving on its data channels, or null if SCTP negotiation hasn't happened.

RTCPeerConnectionSetConfiguration.summary:
The setConfiguration() method of the interface sets the current configuration of the connection based on the values included in the specified object.
This lets you change the ICE servers used by the connection and which transport policies to use.

remarks.para: The most common use case for this method (and even then, probably not a very common use case) is to replace the set of ICE servers to be used. Two potential scenarios in which this might be done:

blockquote.para: You cannot change the identity information for a connection once it's already been set.

RTCPeerConnectionSetIdentityProvider.summary:
The setIdentityProvider() method of the interface sets the Identity Provider (IdP) to the triplet given in parameter: its name, the protocol used to communicate with it (optional) and an optional username.
The IdP will be used only when an assertion is needed.

remarks.para: If the is set to "closed", an InvalidStateError is raised.
-WebRTC

RTCPeerConnectionSetLocalDescription.summary:
The setLocalDescription() method of the interface changes the local description associated with the connection.
This description specifies the properties of the local end of the connection, including the media format.
The method takes a single parameterthe session descriptionand it returns a which is fulfilled once the description has been changed, asynchronously.

remarks.para:
If setLocalDescription() is called while a connection is already in place, it means renegotiation is underway (possibly to adapt to changing network conditions).
Because descriptions will be exchanged until the two peers agree on a configuration, the description submitted by calling setLocalDescription() does not immediately take effect.
Instead, the current connection configuration remains in place until negotiation is complete. Only then does the agreed-upon configuration take effect.

-WebRTC API
-

RTCPeerConnectionSetLocalDescription.returns:
A {{jsxref("Promise")}} which is fulfilled once the value of is successfully changed or rejected if the change cannot be applied (for example, if the specified description is incompatible with one or both of the peers on the connection).
The promise's fulfillment handler receives no input parameters.
NOTEThe process of changing descriptions actually involves intermediary steps handled by the WebRTC layer to ensure that an active connection can be changed without losing the connection if the change does not succeed.
See Pending and current descriptions in the WebRTC Connectivity page for more details on this process.

RTCPeerConnectionSetRemoteDescription.summary:
The setRemoteDescription() method of the interface sets the specified session description as the remote peer's current offer or answer.
The description specifies the properties of the remote end of the connection, including the media format.
The method takes a single parameterthe session descriptionand it returns a which is fulfilled once the description has been changed, asynchronously.

remarks.para:
This is typically called after receiving an offer or answer from another peer over the signaling server.
Keep in mind that if setRemoteDescription() is called while a connection is already in place, it means renegotiation is underway (possibly to adapt to changing network conditions).

Because descriptions will be exchanged until the two peers agree on a configuration, the description submitted by calling setRemoteDescription() does not immediately take effect.
Instead, the current connection configuration remains in place until negotiation is complete.
Only then does the agreed-upon configuration take effect.

-WebRTC
-,
,
-

RTCPeerConnectionSetRemoteDescription.returns:
A {{jsxref("Promise")}} which is fulfilled once the value of the connection's is successfully changed or rejected if the change cannot be applied (for example, if the specified description is incompatible with one or both of the peers on the connection).
The promise fulfillment handler receives no input parameters.
NOTEThe process of changing descriptions actually involves intermediary steps handled by the WebRTC layer to ensure that an active connection can be changed without losing the connection if the change does not succeed.
See Pending and current descriptions in the WebRTC Connectivity page for more details on this process.

RTCPeerConnectionSignalingState.summary:
The signalingState read-only property of the interface returns a string value describing the state of the signaling process on the local end of the connection while connecting or reconnecting to another peer.
See Signaling in our WebRTC session lifetime page.

remarks.para:
Because the signaling process is a state machine, being able to verify that your code is in the expected state when messages arrive can help avoid unexpected and avoidable failures.
For example, if you receive an answer while the signalingState isn't "have-local-offer", you know that something is wrong, since you should only receive answers after creating an offer but before an answer has been received and passed into . Your code will be more reliable if you watch for mismatched states like this and handle them gracefully.
This value may also be useful during debugging, for example.
In addition, when the value of this property changes, a event is sent to the instance.

-Lifetime of a WebRTC session
-
-
-WebRTC

RTCPeerConnectionSignalingstatechange.summary: A signalingstatechange event is sent to an to notify it that its signaling state, as indicated by the property, has changed.

remarks.para: This event is not cancelable and does not bubble.

-WebRTC API
-

RTCPeerConnectionTrack.summary: The track event is sent to the ontrack event handler on s after a new track has been added to an which is part of the connection.

remarks.para: By the time this event is delivered, the new track has been fully added to the peer connection. See Track event types for details.
This event is not cancellable and does not bubble.
